text:
So before I get started,
just a quick raise of hands.

How many people here might
actually use Twitter? A couple, cool. Awesome.

We have work to do
to get all of you. But before that
happens, before we get started, if you could tweet
your favorite song to @RChoi.

RChoi, that's me. And it's part of the demo. As I'm talking, rambling,
feel free to just think,

I don't want to
listen to this guy. I'll just tweet a
song title to @RChoi. And please keep it clean,
please keep it classy.

So what I'm here to
talk about is connecting

to the pulse of the planet
from the Twitter perspective or-- before I get
started actually, a little bit about myself.

This is me, my sister,
and my two kids. I graduated from UC Berkeley
computer science in 2000.

Great computer science program. I was an early engineer
at Salesforce.com. I built the APIs.

That was a phenomenal
experience. I was there for a
great eight years and really got a
chance to learn how to build scalable
software systems.

At some point or
another, I decided that it was time to
go back to school. That was 12 years later
or 10 years later, so I went back to
business school.

It was an interesting
complement. I'm happy to talk
to anyone who's considering business
school or seeing how business and
technology work together.

I met my co-founder for a
start up called Style Up. And we got into Y Combinator.

That was a great experience to
be near Paul Graham, Gary Tan, and all these luminaries
that you hear about. And they really are
as smart as you hear,

so that was an
amazing experience. And lastly, I'm now a
developer advocate at Twitter.

Of the many things I've
done that I've enjoyed, this is one of my favorite
jobs I've ever had. A ton of fun, I
get to speak, I get

to show what people are doing
with cool things on Twitter. Hopefully I'll show
some things with you.

And just as a plug,
we are hiring. So if you're interested and
want to work in the city, feel free to meet me afterwards.

So when I go out
on the occasions that I'm actually fortunate
to go out and talk to people,

I normally hear three questions. Number one is, why should
I build into Twitter? I love talking to engineers.

And I think that
there's so many things you can do on social media,
people want to know why Twitter

and how can it help. The next thing is, how
do I build into Twitter? Well, great. Now that maybe I've given
a couple of examples,

how do I do that? And I want to show
some examples of that. So that's the third
point, is just showing other great
examples that we've built

as well as that have
been out in the wild. And hopefully those
will inspire you to pick up some of our tools,
some of our open source

libraries on GitHub and
start poking around. So the first question of
why build into Twitter--

and if you are having the
conversation, hashtag open webcam six. Twitter, first off, enables
global distribution.

And that can mean
one of two things. If you are an app developer
or if you are a web developer

and you've built
this awesome thing, you can use Twitter
to get distribution to get people to see it.

And if you're a
publisher, you can use Twitter to get your
content distributed.

Viral content, great
content, gets shared widely, and that's what people love
and that's what they retweet

and that's what they
want to talk about. So different people
have different examples

of what great content is. Just three examples right
here, a lot of people love Twitter for sports.

And so the NFL shares live
video clips as they happen or right after they happen. And they get a ton
of distribution.

People love watching
the video clip and then having the conversation
about it on Twitter.

People love selfies. Selfies are a thing now. And here's a selfie
with the pope.

And so it's not
just these brands that are going out there
and sending their message. It's individuals having
their experiences,

their voice distributed
on our platform. And news distribution,
this was a photo

from the unfortunate
crash at SFO. It was actually taken by a
man who was on the flight,

got out, took a picture. And then soon after, this is
not just the conversation,

this is actually all the places
where that image and that tweet were syndicated.

So you'll see that some
of the major news sources actually had this
as the key piece,

they keynote of the story. Add to that that image, that
story got then distributed

on television, got distributed
on lots of different channels. And so this event was
breaking on Twitter

and spread throughout the world. One interesting note
that I like to use for this particular
example is-- have

any of you used the social
media application Path? A few of you. So Twitter, Facebook, larger
groups-- Path, their premise

is that it's a smaller
social network, but you can share to the
larger social networks. This guy, this man
David, was actually

using Path at that time. And he clicked on the photo,
wrote his little message,

sent it out to
his social network and shared it on Twitter. And so through this
integration, this application

was able to get a
ton of distribution and a ton of downloads
because it got visibility because it was a great
story being told.

So from where we stand on the
developer advocacy promoting the APIs, we want people
to bring great content

into Twitter and
to do what we can to help it get great
distribution to lots of people because there are
amazing stories

and amazing applications
that people want to see and want to hear about.

Other reasons that people
like integrating into Twitter,

we're growing in terms
of our user base. At this point this might
be a little outdated, but 230 million
active users, I think

550 tweets on a daily basis. And that 77% of the
users are actually

outside of the United States. And so we get a ton of
distribution globally. We're super excited about being
able to have the conversation

not just be local, not just
be where you are, but just around the world. The things that
you're interested in,

the things that you
follow can be anywhere. And we're pretty
happy about that.

That leads into how
we see as developers. But just as people who people
who love and work at Twitter,

if you're building anything
that requires distribution, there's a built-in
nature of Twitter

where there's all these
conversations happening and you're plugging into that. So if you like movies
and you like television,

right, there's a conversation
happening around the Oscars and the selfie that
took down Twitter. But it just had a tremendous
amount of popularity

and a tremendous
amount of distribution. If you like science,
Nasa has amazing Twitter

handle where they share photos
that are literally breaking to the world or to
human eyes and are

breaking on Twitter that just
get a ton of distribution. Because it's great
content again, and a great distribution,
a great channel

for spreading your word out. LeBron James, a
little timely, but he

had this tweet, which
"I'm not MJ, I'm LJ." And now he's [INAUDIBLE].

37,000 favorites, 100,000
basically engagements and counting.

you'll follow LeBron James
to see what he's saying, to see what that
conversation is about.

And if you are into finance and
you want the best, new, hottest

tips on how to trade, how to
invest, this is Drake saying, hey, the first million is the
hardest, kind of being Drake.

And then T. Boone
Pickens-- who's actually a
billionaire-- replying to him saying, actually,
the first billion is

a hell of a lot harder. And so this is a conversation. This is what actually
happens on Twitter.

And we're just amazed to see
how these conversations go, where people step up,
where people step down.

And Drake said, you
know, T. Boone Pickens? You just dumped it on me heavy. So these things are happening.

These are the conversations
that are happening on Twitter. And by building apps, by
building publications,

by reaching out to
these people you're plugging into these
conversations and these groups, these interests
that already exist.

Lastly, here at Twitter
one of the things

that we pride ourselves on
is being open and real time. We feel that it's essential that
everyone's voice gets heard,

everyone gets distribution, and
the greatest, the best content is the one that people share.

And that it is absolutely
real time, right? It is platform of now, the
platform of what's happening.

Both from developers
and both from users, you get to see how news are
unfolding as they unfold

and as they get distributed. One of the
visualizations that we have around our office-- if
you're ever around the office,

feel free to hit me a message
and I'm happy to have you over. We visualize-- using Vine,
at least in this case.

We have these large
screens where we actually show tweets happening in
real time around the world.

So there's Asia,
there's America. And it's just humbling
to be there and just to see these conversations
happening in thinking, what

can we do to help get people's
voices distributed and spread?

In line with that, we've
had other companies do visualizations or
analysis of conversations that are happening on Twitter.

Because they're
open, because you can see who's following
who, because you can see the interconnectedness
of people,

they did a-- this
company, Electionista did a map of the various
countries in the Middle East

and how they were connected,
both in terms of conversations as well as followers. And so here in the
top left you'll

see Lebanon, Jordan,
Qatar, Kuwait. The circles are actually
the influencers,

the key people who speak. And the lines are actually how
they're having conversations or how they're being followed.

And so there's this
whole conversation that's happening with anything
that's happening, whether it's start ups or
politics or so forth,

and Twitter's
mapping those things. Maybe we're not
ourselves mapping them, but there are certainly
other companies

who are looking at
that information and seeing how these
conversations are unfolding and how these influencers are
happening to shape events.

So people ask, why
build into Twitter?

We feel that's the key
things are just distribution at real-time global
scale, connecting users

to their interests
regardless of whether or not you're promoting your local
shop or your ESPN trying

to get content distributed. And the fact that it's
open in real-time we feel is an advantage for
both transparency

but for making sure
that your voice is heard and you're getting the latest
information at any given point.

So hopefully those are
some interesting reasons that you might want
to build into Twitter.

And then the question is, well,
how do I build into Twitter? And so we'll share
some examples.

But for that we have some
cards out in the back that we're going to share. We have streaming APIs,
which you can, basically,

for a developer latch
onto and get tons and tons and tons of tweets
streamed at you and do whatever
you want with them.

We have the REST APIs so you can
do more transactional things, like we had that Path example. Click a button, post a photo,
post a comment to Twitter.

We have Twitter cards. So at the very beginning
of the presentation, we showed the videos of the NFL
showing video clips on Twitter.

And Twitter cards
enabled that distribution through Twitter's platform. We do a bunch of
stuff in open source,

which some people
are familiar with. Has anybody here used
Twitter Bootstrap? Show of hands. You guys like it?

It's OK? It's cool? Yeah? Cool. I'm a hack, so when someone
can make something that's

visually beautiful or good
enough that I can run with, I love it. But we have a bunch of
other open source libraries

that you guys should
also check out. We have [INAUDIBLE],
things that help scale that we have open source and
other fortune 500 companies are

actually using. And you can just go to t.co/apps
or apps.twitter.com to get

started to create
your first app. You'll get auth
tokens and so forth and you'll be able to
plug right into Twitter.

To give a little
background of what you'll

expect when you
plug into Twitter, this is one of the first tweets. Jack Dorsey, our founder,
set up this simple message,

"just setting up my Twitter." 140 characters, people
look at this and they say, hmm, that's interesting
kinda sorta.

What can I do with that? We think any individual
tweet certainly has a lot of reach
if it's an amazing

or if it's an amazing content
or if it's someone's voice. But it actually
is 140 characters

with 4 kilobytes of information. And so when you're
looking at this tweet, you may just see text.

What you actually have
is location, associations whom you're tweeting
who've replied responses,

the popularity,
tweets, retweets. And so there's a whole
set of information, 4 kilobytes, at scale
at 550 million a day

is certainly a ton
of data to work with. It may not be the
precise information

that a lot of
people use, but when you start adding language
processing analytics

on those kinds of things you
can start getting sentiment. You can start seeing how people
are feeling about things, what

they're watching, what
they're not watching. You can get a pretty
good sense of what's

going on actually in the world. The first time I heard that
working at Twitter I was like, come on, really?

But we actually have
one the largest corpuses of human thought with
550 million tweets.

I believe they say
it'll take like 13 years to read just if it were a book.

So there's a ton of information. There's a ton of people
expressing amazing things on Twitter.

You can get that individually
through our REST APIs transactional, or you
can get the stream.

And so if you were
to take those tweets and just put them back to
back to back to back to back, that's what you get.

And that's just a
little piece of it. So building into Twitter
is actually as simple as doing a post to--
this is our filter API.

You might specify on
the URL parameters who I follow, what you're
tracking, open webcam. And you can even
specify locations

and you can get a stream
that's specific to that area or to that filter.

You can get a stream that
is the sample stream, which is 1% of the firehose. A lot of people come
and they say, hey,

I want all the tweets. I want everything. Just give me it all. At 550 million in a
day, I promise you,

you do not want all of them. I've tried even with the 1%,
and it's a lot to take in

and there's a lot of data. Start using that. Start playing around with that. Start collecting that data
and doing analysis on that.

As your need grows, feel
free to reach out to us. We're happy to work with you. But trust me, 1%
of 550 is plenty.

And it is statistically
relevant, again. There's like a
good enough sample set where you're looking
at a good chunk of data

with what people are saying. And then we also have
the all the firehose

which we mentioned. And so just as an
example, again, there are some amazing talks
already that I'm not

going to one up by any means. But just to get an
idea of how easy it is to build into Twitter, we
have-- get it start started.

We have a GitHub
account @TwitterDev. So you just go to
github.com, Twitter Dev. We have a number of code bases.

But the one that
is pretty popular, or that we kind of like,
is a ruby example we have,

uses firehose or
the sample stream. So you just go here,
you click on here.

You guys just do
a Git clone, you can get everything you need.

Yep, you can get
everything you need. As I mentioned before,
you create an application.

So you go to apps.twitter.com,
you create application details, description. In doing, so you'll
get your auth tokens

to get your whatever you
need to connect to Twitter. And with just a
little bit of code

in this particular
example, right here you would put your tokens, which
is just a simple YAML file.
I can't-- what is it right here?

There are actually two examples. I have a bit of a
messy PlayBook here.

We've done a pretty
simple example. A guy named Andrew's, who's just
hooked this up with websockets,

you can take a look at the
code that we have here. It listens to websockets. It listens to just all
these tweet coming through.

It handles them we've. Integrated with Google Maps. It's almost like the first
thing that people do, and we're trying to
make it super simple

to be the first-- probably be
the first thing that people do. And you get a fairly simple
streaming example, right?

And this one shows the tweets
happening on the left hand side. It shows them being
located all over.

And then a you
change the location, it'll actually change
the filter and just

show the treets in that area. So you're getting that stream
based on just a certain area. It's pretty amazing when
you start looking at it,

you start diving in. You're like, these
are actual people in these actual places actually
talking about things right now.

It sounds little weird,
but as you zoom out,

again, you just start seeing
the scale at which you're operating. And this is actually
throttled a bit

as well because it's a
pretty simple example. You can actually go to
twitterdevdemo.com/maps.

That's where it's hosted. We just have some these
examples out there. But you get a scale of like,
yes, this could actually be the body of thought
of people in an area

or potentially even the world,
if you were to be so bold. We're happy that Monica and
Sophia and Rachel and Penny

and everyone is talking
about and using Twitter. So that's one example.

And then not to jump
around too much, but just to show a
couple of other examples

that we particularly love with
brands and with our own code, here's an example of a
company called bluefin

that was actually acquired
by Twitter because of the amazing things that they
were doing with Twitter data
at scale. There's a talk track. You probably can't hear it. I might have to just mute it.

Great. So we all know that
Twitter and sports, they go pretty well together.

Here is the Super Bowl. And this is a visualization
of all the tweets happening

during the Superbowl,
time indexed. And so this is the conversation,
13.4 million people

talking about the
Superbowl on Twitter. And bluefin went actually and
time sequenced important events

in the Super Bowl,
including the half time-- and you can see that little
piece about commercials-- and saw who was talking
about which commercials, what

were the most popular plays,
and what was going on. Right, so they've overlaid
all this information,

but the key thing
being that if you have the conversation
that's happening, real-time, about a
TV event-- and more

specifically,
about commercials-- you can imagine that
broadcasters who-- you know,

who's watching? I'm not too sure. Well again, a statistically
relevant sample of the population is on Twitter.

And so when that conversation is
happening, we can reliably say, this percentage of the
US, or even the world,

is watching this show at
this time as it's happening. So those are the kinds of things
that bluefin has been doing.

And you can imagine there
are other companies that are taking this to different
verticals or different use cases. So we're super excited
about the possibilities

that you can do with the
data and the creativity that can be unleashed, if you will.

There's also this
thing that Starbucks does called Tweet a Coffee. Has anybody heard
of this at all? One person, so thank you.

It's actually pretty
straightforward. You go onto Twitter. And this is me doing it.

You just say @TweetACoffe
to Brian Bloom is the person I
did it back then, but this is my
willing participant.

Thanks for having
me @infobrook-- it was the event-- and then
down below, who replies? Starbucks does.
Starbucks says, hey Brian. Ryan just tweeted you a coffee. Click on this link.

And literally when
you click on the link and you do a quick OAuth,
you have $5 in your account.

Did it work? I hope. AUDIENCE: I think it would
have [INAUDIBLE] permissions

that they ask for on
the app is pretty much everything in the world. RYAN CHOI: Oh, for
the Starbucks app? AUDIENCE: They can
tweet to my name,

they can change my profile
and read all my tweet. RYAN CHOI: OK, I'll
talk to them about that. Fair enough, fair enough.

If anybody else
want a coffee, I am happy to meet you out
back and give you a coffee if you want to give all your
information to Starbucks.

AUDIENCE: They're
buying your information. RYAN CHOI: They're
buying the information. They actually don't do a
ton with that information.

They actually just see this as
just a very natural marketing use case, and to effectively
have the conversation,

have Starbucks be
the conversation in a very natural way. One of the things that we
do in developer advocacies

is we try to show or we try
to help developers and brands bring their voice to
Twitter in a way that

makes real sense on Twitter. And so certainly you
could take content and you could
broadcast it, you can

have the ads-- which do work
and do have clickthrough-- but this was something that
was very natural on Twitter

and just kept the conversation
going in an evergreen conversation. It launched more than a year ago
and people are still doing it.

And Starbucks has this continual
conversation about their brand out there. Great marketing, but it
actually drives revenue.

So feel free to use it some
time with maybe a friend who

love Starbucks and already
has the app installed and give it a shot.

So I asked you guys you to
also to tweet at me a song. We'll figure out what song
you tweeted at me right now.
I'm crossing my fingers. Let's see here. And so-- let's see here.

"The Next Episode," by Dr.
Dre, done by-- ha ha, maybe not

that one. We'll do this one.
"Welcome to the Jungle," De la Soul, "I Know."

So effectively what
this is doing is this is just a quick
integration that we

did because we got invited
to the Spotify hackathon, and so we put this
together really quickly.

It was actually a music
hackathon in San Francisco, it wasn't just the
Spotify hackathon. And we were able to work with
a lot of the music companies

there. Beasts was one of them. They wanted to launch this
new web-based audio player.

And so we did a really quick
integration where you log in via Twitter, you
log in via Beats,

and you let people just tweet
you and it creates a playlist. So the thinking was
that this actually

was playing in the background,
because we launched it before the hackathon
itself to let people

have music going on background. I've also used this for a
couple of barbecues and whatnot

with friends. And we're just trying
to show that there are a lot of interesting things
that you can do on Twitter

and give people both
ideas as well sample code. I'm happy to show
you where this is. It's under my own
personal GitHub account.

But super simple to do,
it took a couple days to put it together. And an interesting
use case of Twitter
is a communication channel.
And let's see.

Other crazy things that our team
goes out there and does and we think are cool with devices,
so this is one of our developer

advocates, one of my peers,
[? Romaine ?] [? Hewitt ?] in the UK. He is fascinated with drones.

And so I wish I could give this
talk, this would be amazing. But he takes a drone,
he sits on a table. He tweets at it, and it flies.

He's taken Raspberry Pi, kind
of connected that together. And I've seen it once,
and I was just like, whoa. Bow down.

Just amazing. And then he runs
into the crowd and he takes a picture of himself
by tweeting take a picture.

Takes a snap and then
posts it to Twitter. So bravo, [? Romaine. ?]
I wish I could show you. But these are all things
that you can do with the API.

They're actually on
our GitHub account. He's got the-- it's
called Node Copter. He's got the libraries
for flying the node

with the APIs for
the Twitter and I think even the
Raspberry Pi stuff. So if anyone is interested,
I'm happy to show you or learn,

sit down and learn
with you and figure out how we can go build
this together.

So hopefully I've given examples
of what the Twitter API is able to do, maybe even inspired
you a little bit of why

you use the API
for distribution, for bringing great
content, or for tapping into the conversations that are
already happening on Twitter.

And there's a bunch of code
out there to just get started. I'm here to help.

TwitterDev, our entire developer
advocacy team, is here to help. You can Google
Twitter API Libraries

and learn a lot of things. Again, we have cards
out there in the back. And just feel free
to tweet me @RChoi.

I'm happy to chat with
anybody and get you started and see how I can help.
And that's the talk. Questions? Yes? Oh. [APPLAUSE]

AUDIENCE: So there's no
charge for the 1% fee? RYAN CHOI: Correct. So the question is, is there
a charge for the 1% fee?

There is no charge. You can just get started. As it scales up, because
it is something of a cost,

getting the full feed does have
if not a charge at least some kind of-- not restrictions, but
there are some terms around it.

But again, that 1%,
you c an get started. You can download
that ruby example and get going immediately.

Other questions? AUDIENCE: How do you
get your revenue? RYAN CHOI: How do we--? AUDIENCE: --get your revenue. RYAN CHOI: Oh, great.

Great question. So we have a bunch, a number
of ways that we make revenue.

Brands use Twitter as
a distribution channel. So when they have a tweet out
there, when they have content and they want to broadcast
that more widely,

you can actually
promote a tweet. You can even target tweets
to your target audience. So say that, just as an example,
if NFL wanted to make sure

that that video reached more
people, they could promote it. They could target it, age
demographics, location,

and get it in front
of the right audience. We also have the ability to get
lead generation, if you will.

And so you can actually
take-- you can actually have a card that can gauge
interest for maybe a flyer

or for news or for information
and then share your email address all in the open where
it says you are doing this.

And then the brand
collects email address for distribution
lists and so forth.

And there's a number
of products like that. AUDIENCE: So if I had
a business, that's

what I would
eventually [INAUDIBLE]? RYAN CHOI: Yes. And we encourage people
to start using it

in kind of the organic
sense and kind of understand what message resonates
with your audience and where you want to be.

And to just get started it
doesn't cost anything at all. Create a Twitter account, go
on, follow brands and accounts

that you like. And people build relationships. I've met a ton of
people on Twitter before meeting
them in real life.

And it's not a
substitute for anything. You go out there,
you're on this platform and you make
connections with people.

And that leads into
things with Drake and T. Boone Pickens
going back and forth

on Twitter very organically. Other questions? Yes. AUDIENCE: I'm
curious-- [INAUDIBLE] RYAN CHOI: That's
a good question.

So the question is,
what initiatives do we have to get more
distribution or get more awareness to the
broader population?

Have you seen some
of the stuff that we might have been doing in the
World Cup at all recently? AUDIENCE: I did, yeah. RYAN CHOI: Cool.

So we, for the World
Cup specifically, we had a new user flow whereby if
you are interested in the World

Cup, it will, number one,
get you to sign up and then immediately ask you, OK, you
were interested in the World

Cup? Yes. What is your team? And by knowing
your team, we then suggest players and teams that
are relevant to that area.

And so you can see our--
I wouldn't say focus, but one of the
things we're doing is saying around
events or around things

that are more topical,
bringing people into a new user experience where
you have the context

and you're brought in
immediately following people to understand what the
conversations look like. So the conversation is,
what is the relationship

between Twitter and TV, and how
is that-- is that an initiative that Twitter is doing, or
that we're bringing with TV?

We work with a
lot of publishers, a lot of broadcasters. And I think part of
serendipity in part is how can we partner together
to, if you're a broadcaster,

they want to make sure the
conversation is continuing. They want to make sure
they're getting distribution. So they come to us and they
say, hey, what things can we do?

And we'd love to be a
part of the conversation for many different
verticals, and so TV just being one of them.

So I'd say it's more of
a coming to the table and saying, hey, what
awesome things can we do together, more than us
pushing it or them pushing it.

It really comes down to, if
people are tweeting about it, if people are talking about
television shows, game of thrones, Super
Bowl, World Cup,

we want to be that channel for
that real-time conversation. And whoever it makes
sense to partner with

or whoever comes to us, we're
happy to work with them. Another question back there?

What happens to them,
so we have algorithms-- so the question is, if you
have shady accounts following

you or spamming
